UI_visible_response: Read 40 web pagesView Page DetailsThe Jasmine Revolution refers to the popular uprising in Tunisia that took place from December 17, 2010, to January 14, 2011. It was triggered by the self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi, a 26-year-old street vendor, who set himself on fire to protest government corruption and economic hardship. His act became a symbol of the widespread discontent among Tunisians facing high unemployment, poverty, and political repression under President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali.The protests quickly spread across the country, leading to violent clashes with police and the eventual ousting of Ben Ali, who fled the country on January 14, 2011. This marked the end of his 23-year rule and was the first successful overthrow of an Arab authoritarian regime during the Arab Spring. The Jasmine Revolution inspired similar uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa, collectively known as the Arab Spring.In the aftermath, Tunisia embarked on a transition to democracy. A new constitution was drafted and promulgated in January 2014, and the country held its first free elections. Tunisia's Jasmine Revolution is often cited as the only Arab Spring uprising that resulted in a stable democratic government.CopyTry AgainShare
traffic_visible_response: The Jasmine Revolution refers to the popular uprising in Tunisia that took place from December 17, 2010, to January 14, 2011[^7^]. It was triggered by the self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi, a 26-year-old street vendor, who set himself on fire to protest government corruption and economic hardship[^1^][^3^]. His act became a symbol of the widespread discontent among Tunisians facing high unemployment, poverty, and political repression under President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali[^1^][^7^].The protests quickly spread across the country, leading to violent clashes with police and the eventual ousting of Ben Ali, who fled the country on January 14, 2011[^1^][^7^]. This marked the end of his 23-year rule and was the first successful overthrow of an Arab authoritarian regime during the Arab Spring[^1^][^2^]. The Jasmine Revolution inspired similar uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa, collectively known as the Arab Spring[^1^][^2^].In the aftermath, Tunisia embarked on a transition to democracy. A new constitution was drafted and promulgated in January 2014, and the country held its first free elections[^2^][^7^]. Tunisia's Jasmine Revolution is often cited as the only Arab Spring uprising that resulted in a stable democratic government[^1^].
